DOCNAME: CASE OF HIRO BALANI v. SPAIN
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . PERSON was at the material time an NORP national ; she subsequently obtained NORP nationality . She lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE the NORP company " ORG " - which specialised in the manufacture and distribution of clocks - filed an application in the GPE no . CARDINAL ORG for the removal of the NORP trade mark " PERSON Málaga " ( no . CARDINAL.CARDINAL ) from the industrial property register . The trade mark in question concerned " all types of clocks " and had been registered by the applicant ’s husband in DATE . It had at a later stage been transferred to her name . The plaintiff company claimed that , by virtue of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the registration in GPE in DATE of its trade name had conferred on it the ownership of that designation in all the countries which were parties to that Convention - including GPE - and therefore protected it from the subsequent lodging of any identical or similar trade mark .
CARDINAL . PERSON adduced several submissions to contest the application . They were based on the following considerations :
CARDINAL . DATE within which the cancellation of trade mark no . CARDINAL.CARDINAL could have been sought had expired and the trade mark was consequently " established " .
CARDINAL . Any action was time - barred .
CARDINAL . The trade name relied on by the plaintiff company was not a genuine one .
CARDINAL . A trade mark " ORG " , for imitation articles , that had been registered in DATE under no . CARDINAL and transferred to the applicant ’s name in DATE , had priority .

CARDINAL . ORG By a judgment dated CARDINAL DATE , ORG , the court with jurisdiction for this type of dispute ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , accepted the contention that PERSON mark was " established " and dismissed the plaintiff ’s application . It did not rule on the merits of the applicant ’s other submissions .

CARDINAL . ORG The plaintiff company appealed on points of law . In a judgment of DATE ORG Tribunal Supremo ) held that the contested trade mark was not " established " because its registration was void and quashed the decision of LOC . Giving a ruling on the merits of the dispute ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , ORG expressly rejected the submissions based on the allegedly non - genuine character of the trading name and the general time bar and allowed the application . However , it made no reference to the applicant ’s submission that the trade mark " ORG " , registered in GPE in DATE , should have priority over the trading name " LOC " registered in GPE in DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant filed an amparo appeal ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) in ORG ) . It was declared inadmissible on DATE on the ground that the various complaints adduced did not raise constitutional issues . On the matter of the submission relating to the priority of the trade mark " ORG " , ORG expressed the following view :

" ... as this issue was not put forward as a ground of appeal , the ORG [ of ORG ] could hardly be expected to address it directly . Moreover , there is extensive case - law from this ORG to the effect that the LAW does not require courts to give a specific reply to all the arguments of the parties but only their claims . In the instant case [ the applicant ’s ] submission was rejected when the appeal on points of law filed by the plaintiff against the first - instance judgment was allowed . "
As decisions of ORG finding an appeal inadmissible may be reconsidered only on an application by ORG counsel , a further appeal lodged by PERSON was likewise declared inadmissible on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG The rules governing trade marks and trade names which were in force at the material time were set out in ORG ( Estatuto de la Propiedad Industrial , " EPI " ) of DATE , approved by LAW of DATE . The enactment in DATE of a new law on trade marks did not affect the applicability of that regulation to the facts of the present case .

CARDINAL . ORG The registration in GPE of a trade mark or a trade name confers on its holder standing to bring proceedings in the civil and criminal courts against those who infringe his right ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL EPI ) . The priority of rights deriving from a trade mark or a trade name takes effect from the filing of the application for registration in the industrial property register ( LAW ) .

The holder of a registered trade name has the same rights as those conferred on the holder of a trade mark ( LAW ) . He may , inter alia , seek the removal from the register of any mark ( LAW ) whose similarity with the trade name might give rise to an error or create confusion in the market ( LAW para . CARDINAL EPI ) . In order to make such a finding of incompatibility , the court will examine not only the phonetic or graphic similarity of the CARDINAL competing designations ; it will also consider whether the protected products belong to the same commercial sector .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW for the protection of industrial property of DATE , as amended in GPE on DATE - which version was ratified by GPE on DATE - , provides that a trade name registered in CARDINAL of the countries of the ORG is to be protected in all the other countries of the Union without necessity of deposit or registration ( LAW . Since such a trade name is entitled to the same protection as if it had been registered in GPE , its holder may seek the removal from the register of any NORP mark registered after the trade name in question and incompatible with it .

CARDINAL . ORG Article CARDINAL EPI makes provision for a special procedure for applying for the removal of a trade mark from the official register . The first - instance court prepares the file and transmits it to LOC , which seeks the opinion of the legal department of the industrial property register and holds a hearing .

CARDINAL . Judgments given at first instance by LOC concerning the removal of trade marks from the register may be challenged only by an appeal on points of law to ORG ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL EPI ) .

The complaints concerning the impugned judgment must be expressed in the form of grounds for cassation ( motivos de casación - Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure ) , of which there are a limited number , for instance failure to comply with essential procedural requirements and violation of the law ( LAW , nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure ) .

CARDINAL . Argument is presented on the submissions declared admissible , at a public hearing if all the parties so request or if the court considers it necessary . The respondent may appear and plead for the dismissal of the appeal and the confirmation of the impugned judgment ( Articles DATE in fine and DATE of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Except in respect of purely formal or procedural matters , the ORG which allows an appeal submission does not merely quash the judgment . It must rule on the merits of the case , taking account of all the arguments adduced by the parties in the course of the proceedings ( DATE para . CARDINAL paragraph , of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW , " judgments shall always contain a statement of the grounds on which they are based and be delivered in public " . As an aspect of the effective protection of individuals by the judiciary and the courts , recognised as a fundamental right by LAW para . CARDINAL of the LAW , the obligation to state the reasons for judicial decisions may be the subject of an individual appeal to ORG ( recurso de amparo ) .
CARDINAL . ORG According to LAW :

" Judgments must be clear and precise and must address specifically the applications and other claims made in the course of the proceedings ; they must find for or against the defendant and rule on all the disputed points which have been the subject of argument .
Such points must be dealt with separately in the judgment . "

When a court gives a decision on the merits it must therefore rule on all the submissions adduced by the parties , otherwise the judgment will be flawed for failure to give an adequate statement of the grounds ( incongruencia omisiva ) . However , according to the case - law , the court is not under a duty to deal expressly in its judgment with each of the submissions made by the parties where its decision to allow CARDINAL of the claims entails by implication the rejection of the submission in question .
